titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Miss Brown this afternoon visited Mrs: Adams— Visit from Mr: Livingston— Walk twice in the park. At the Casino in the Evening. Had a lesson from Mr: Catel this day, and wrote to Mr: Murray.

2. The first warm, summer’s day— In the evening a thunder shower— Mr: Livingstone and Mr: Arbuthnot, Miss Brühl, and Miss Pauline Neale to visit Mrs: Adams— Evening at Belle-vue— Played Reversi, with Madame de Sartoris, M. de Sydow, and Count Lottum— Did not stay to supper— Mrs: Adams spent the Evening at Mrs: Brown’s.

3. Busily engaged upon translation— Went to the Chasseur’s, a garden in the park, and took tea with Count Brühl and his family—being his daughter Mary’s birth day— Weather damp and cold— The gnats troublesome. Dr: Brown came out and sent us all home to his house— Played chess with him.— After supper Mr: Terry sung a number of songs, very well.

4. In the forenoon at Mr: Schickler,s which shortened much this day’s work.— Walked in the park towards Evening. Met Prince Augustus riding alone on horseback— Afterwards passed an hour at the Casino.

5. Busied more than usual, to make up for yesterday’s deficiency.— Long walk in the evening, and spent an hour at the Casino, where I found M. de Sartoris.— Countess Golowkin and her daughter came to take leave of Mrs: Adams.— They are going with the Count to spend the summer at Töplitz.

6. Mrs: Adams very unwell— At the play, this evening. Saw a comedy of Kotzebue—Lohn der Wahrheit, or the reward of truth—one of his most indifferent plays, though not objectionable on the side of morality.— Walk to Bellevue, after the play was over.
7. Mrs: A. continues ill. Dr: Brown and Mr: Arbuthnot called in the afternoon. Mrs: Brown in the Evening. Weather at length very fine— Met Mr: Arbuthnot again at the Casino.

8. Finished the first volume of Bülow, and began upon the second— Weather very fine— Evening at Bellevue. Played Reversi, with Madame de Hagen, Count Neale, and Monsr: de Rothenburg— Was at the Casino some time before dinner, to read the hand-bills from Vienna.
9. The summer setting in seriously.— Fine, and warm weather— Day employed as usual— Half an hour this Evening at the Casino.

10— Find my translations more difficult than those of the former volume— Weather excessively warm— A thunder shower in the evening, as usual in this country after a warm day— Walk in the park, and some time at the Casino.

11. Weather quite cool again this day— At a short vocal concert this often, at the Hall where the meetings of the Academy are held.— Walk in the park, and evening at the Casino.— Finished the first quarter of lessons in German from Mr: Catel— Up this morning before 5 o’clock.

12. Began rather late this morning upon my work, and consequently finished less before dinner than usual.— Read a little of Liancourt’s travels.— Walk in the park towards evening, and was then at the Casino, where I found the Austrian chargé des affairs Mr: Hudelist; who has a courier from the Archduke Charles with the account of his having entered Zurich on the 6th: instt:

13— Lesson of German again— Rained the whole day, almost without ceasing— Could not take therefore my usual exercise— Weather so cold, that we had a fire— Was an hour or two at the Casino, in the Evening.— English News-papers.

14. Cold and rainy day again, with much hail— Found an opportunity however in the evening to walk.— At the Casino— Finished reading the first volume of Liancourt’s travels and began the second.— The business which I have pursued for a month past has very much shortened my reading hours.
15. Lesson of German— Weather continues extremely cold and almost constantly rainy— We have had fires these three days.— Walked this Evening— At the Casino till 10.

16. Up so late this morning, that I lost my usual study of German. Day otherwise employed as usual on Sundays. Evening while I was out, Mrs: Brown called upon Mrs: Adams— At the Casino— When I came home, found letters from the Secretary of State—last dated 24. April.

17. My translations absorb as yet almost all my time— I find only an opportunity to walk a quarter of an hour before dinner; and a hour in the evening; which with half an hour at the Casino, constitutes my whole occupation.— This day had of course nothing to distinguish it from many preceding ones.

18. Lesson of German— Letter to Mr: Murray: part of one to the Secretary of State, and my usual portion of translation— Walk in the Evening, and hour at the Casino— Mrs: Adams is again very unwell.— Mrs: Brown called to see her.
19. Mrs: Adams continues unwell.— Finished my letter to the Secretary of State. Walk as usual in the evening and was afterwards at the Casino.— Such a life becomes quite mechanical
20. Lesson of German in the morning— Letters from Mr: Pitcairn and Mr: King.— News-papers from America. Had not time to look into them this day— Walk—and at the Casino.

21. Dined in the park, at Richard’s; by invitation from Mr: & Mrs: Cohen; it being Dr: Brown’s birth day.— His family, with Lord Talbot, Mr: Arbuthnot, Mr Garlike and Mr: Curtoys, made the company.— William Brown who is unwell, came home with me— Evening at Dr: Brown’s— Played whist with him; & Mr: & Mrs: Cohen, & Mr: Richard. Wrote all my translation before dinner.

22.— Visit this forenoon from Mr: Cunningham, a gentleman from Baltimore.— Rose very early and had a lesson of German from Mr: Catel— Various occupations however prevented my finishing the translation untill 8 in the evening— Met in the park with the captain de Ruville, and walked with him— At the Casino, but found nothing from Vienna.

23. Visit this morning from Mr: De Luc; who gave me a copy of his new pamphlet—a letter to the Jews who have lately proposed to renounce their religion, and adopt a sort of Socinian Christianity.— A measure which has produced some sensation here.— Walk as usual; and at the Casino in the evening.

24. Dined with Mr: Grenville— Lord Talbot, Mr: Harris, Admiral Kinckel, Mr: Harris, and Mr: Sievers there. Evening at Bellevue, where a couple of french plays were performed; Arlequin, chien enragé, a very miserable thing, and “La seconde surprise par amour” of Marivaux, which is good and was very well performed; especially the two principal parts by M. and Mad: Sartoris.— After the play the chambers of the house were open, to be looked over— The library appeared to consist almost entirely of french dramatic writers.— After supper, there was a ball; but I did not stay for either— Walked home, before eleven.

25. Was up early to prepare for my lesson of German.— Wrote Mr: Murray, and otherwise found so much time run away in the morning, that I found it necessary to write all the afternoon, and untill almost 9 in the Evening.— Was a few minutes at the Casino, after taking my walk.

26. Was rather more successful in writing this forenoon, and finished somewhat earlier— Walked; and went to the Casino— Mr: Sartoris, there, as he always is on post-days, and Count Bünau, the Saxon Minister.

27. Evening party and supper at the Baron de Hagen’s— Played Whist part of the Evening, with Madame de Saldern, Mlle: de Hoorn, the Chancellor Goldbeck, and the Minister Buchholz.— part of the Evening walked with Mr: Grenville, and Mr: Garlike in the garden.— We had occasion to pass through a back-door, which Mr: Grenville observed, his elder brother could not have ventured to do, because there were a pair of back-stairs— I came home before supper.

28. As I approach towards the conclusion of my translation, I have this day done more than usual. Mrs: Adams, for the first time, went out this afternoon, and spent a couple of hours with Mrs: Brown— I called there for her. Found several young Ladies there; and Mr: Harris & Mr: Winn— Mr: Arbuthnot came in from the play. Mr: Livingstone returns in a few days to England.

29. Finished the translation of Bülow’s book upon America— Wrote a couple of letters— Walking met Mr: Garlike, and Lord Folkstone who is just returned from Russia. In the evening at the play. The two Klingsberg’s—of Kotzebue.

30.— Finished reading the old Testament, began the New.— Miss P. Neale came in the afternoon to see Mrs: Adams—and Mrs: Schickler— Evening at the Casino.— Upon returning home, found letters from America: from my mother and brother.

Day. Rise irregularly from 6 to 8.— Pursue the study of German untill 10. breakfast— translate untill 3.— Walk, half an hour— Dine— Translate again till 7. or read a few pages of German.— Take a long walk. Spend an hour at the Casino— Home and sup at 10.— Play piquet half an hour with my wife, and retire to bed just after eleven— My translations now cease, as I have done Bülows book.
